tc: a bright yellow metal made from copper and zinc
• The door handles were made of brass.門把手是黃銅做的。
a thin piece of brass on the floor or wall in a church, with a picture or writing cut into it
（教堂地上或牆上，刻有雕像或文字的）黃銅紀念牌
• The church has several beautiful medieval brasses.這個教堂有幾塊精美的中世紀黃銅紀念牌。
• The little donkey struggled under its heavy burden.小毛驢馱著重物艱難前行。
something difficult or unpleasant that you have to deal with or worry about
• My elderly mother worries that she's a burden to me.我年邁的母親擔心她成為我的拖累。
• Buying a house often places a large financial burden on young couples.買房子往往會讓年輕夫婦背上沉重的經濟負擔。
• A great number of trees were felled to provide space for grazing.大量樹木被砍伐，為放牧提供場地。
to knock someone down, especially in sports
• （尤指體育運動中）擊倒（某人）他最後以頭部的一記重拳擊倒了對手。
to suddenly go down onto the ground or towards the ground without intending to or by accident
• The path's very steep, so be careful you don't fall.小路很陡，小心別摔倒。
• He fell badly and broke his leg.他重重跌倒，摔斷了腿。
• I fell down the stairs and injured my back.我跌下樓梯，背部受了傷。
to go to another place to get something or someone and bring it, him, or her back
• [ + two objects ] Could you fetch me my glasses/fetch my glasses for me from the other room, please?你去另一個房間幫我把眼鏡拿過來好嗎？
• I have to fetch my mother from the station.我要去車站接我母親。
a group of sheep, goats, or birds
• a flock of sheep/goats/geese一群綿羊／山羊／鵝
• The shepherd is bringing his flock down from the hills.牧羊人正把羊群往山下趕。
a large group of people, usually people of a particular type
• A noisy flock of tourists came into the building.一群吵吵嚷嚷的遊客走進了大樓。
• The priest invited all the members of his flock (= all the people who go to his church) to attend the special service.牧師邀請教區的所有信徒參加這一特別儀式。
• I was late and he was furious with me.我遲到了，他衝我大發脾氣。
• He's furious about/at the way he's been treated.他因自己受到這樣的對待而大發雷霆。
• We had a furious debate about the death penalty.我們就死刑問題吵了個天翻地覆。
using a lot of effort or strength
• There is a furious struggle going on between the two presidential candidates.兩位總統競選人之間進行著激烈的爭鬥。
• He set off running at a furious pace.他出發時猛跑了一陣。
a very small, uncomfortable room at the top of a house
a type of clear butter used in South Asian cooking
（用於南亞食物烹調的）酥油，印度奶油，精鍊奶油
a person who regularly eats and drinks more than is needed
a seed or seeds from a plant, especially a plant like a grass such as rice or wheat
（尤指像稻穀、小麥等像草一樣的植物的）穀粒，穎果，穀（物）
a very small amount of a particular quality
• There wasn't a grain of truth in anything she said.她無論說甚麼都沒有半句實話在裡面。
• Anyone with a grain of common sense would have known what to do.稍微有一點常識的人都會知道應該做甚麼。
to fasten or support something at the top leaving the other parts free to move, or to be held in this way
• A heavy gold necklace hung around her neck.她脖子上掛著一串粗重的金項鍊。
• Party decorations hung (down) from the ceiling.聚會裝飾物從天花板上垂下來。
• The curtains hung in thick folds.窗簾打著密密的摺子垂著。
• Hang your coat and hat (up) on the rack over there.把你的大衣和帽子掛在那邊的架子上。
to fasten or support something at the top leaving the other parts free to move, or to be held in this way
• A heavy gold necklace hung around her neck.她脖子上掛著一串粗重的金項鍊。
• Party decorations hung (down) from the ceiling.聚會裝飾物從天花板上垂下來。
• The curtains hung in thick folds.窗簾打著密密的摺子垂著。
• Hang your coat and hat (up) on the rack over there.把你的大衣和帽子掛在那邊的架子上。
past simple and past participle of hang
to fasten or support something at the top leaving the other parts free to move, or to be held in this way
• A heavy gold necklace hung around her neck.她脖子上掛著一串粗重的金項鍊。
• Party decorations hung (down) from the ceiling.聚會裝飾物從天花板上垂下來。
• The curtains hung in thick folds.窗簾打著密密的摺子垂著。
• Hang your coat and hat (up) on the rack over there.把你的大衣和帽子掛在那邊的架子上。
a very small dried bean that is cooked and eaten
to move the tongue across the surface of something
• He licked the chocolate off his fingers.他把手指上的巧克力舔乾淨了。
• She licked the stamps and stuck them on the parcel.她舔了一下郵票，然後貼在包裹上。
If flames or waves lick something, they pass over it quickly or touch it lightly like a tongue.
（火焰）蔓延，掠過，吞捲；（波浪）拍擊，沖刷
• Within a few seconds flames were licking at the curtains.幾秒鐘之內火舌就蔓延到了窗簾。
behaviour, especially a child's, that is slightly bad but is not intended to cause serious harm or damage
（尤指兒童的）惡作劇，淘氣，搗蛋
• She's a lively little girl, full of mischief.她是一個活潑好動的小姑娘，特別愛淘氣。
• He needs a hobby to keep him busy and stop him from getting into mischief.他需要培養一個愛好讓他有事可忙，不再調皮搗蛋。
• Maybe a new bike would keep him out of mischief.也許一輛新腳踏車會讓他不再淘氣。
• I hope you haven't been up to any mischief while I was gone.我希望我不在時你沒有搞甚麼惡作劇。
kindness that makes you forgive someone, usually someone that you have authority over
• She appealed to the judge to have mercy on her husband.她請求法官寬恕她的丈夫。
• The prisoners pleaded for mercy.囚犯都懇求從輕發落。
• The gunmen showed no mercy, killing innocent men and women.那些槍手毫無憐憫之心，濫殺無辜男女。
an event or situation that you are grateful for because it stops something unpleasant
• After months of suffering, his death was a mercy.遭受了數月痛苦的折磨後，死對他來說是一種解脫。
• They were on a mercy mission to take food to the refugees when they were attacked.他們遇襲時正在執行一項為難民運送食品的救援任務。
• The prisoners ate every last morsel.囚犯把最後一丁點食物都吃了個乾淨。
• a morsel of good news一點點好消息
used to describe a person's face or skin if it has less colour than usual, for example when the person is or ill or frightened, or if it has less colour than people generally have
• You're looking pale - are you feeling well?你看起來臉色蒼白——你病了嗎？
• She has a naturally pale complexion and dark hair.她天生膚色白皙，頭髮烏黑。
A pale light or colour is not bright or strong.
• She wore a pale blue hat.她戴著一頂淺藍色的帽子。
• When no one answered the door, she peered through the window to see if anyone was there.沒有人開門，她就費力地透過窗戶往裡望去，看是否有人在。
• The driver was peering into the distance trying to read the road sign.司機費力地看著遠方，想要看清路標。
used to show that something is possible or that you are not certain about something
• He hasn't written to me recently - perhaps he's lost my address.他最近沒寫信給我——也許他把我的地址弄丟了。
• Perhaps the most important question has not been asked.或許還沒有人提出最重要的問題。
• We plan to travel to Europe - to Spain or Italy perhaps.我們打算去歐洲旅行，也許去西班牙或義大利。
a part or share of something larger
• A large/major portion of the company's profit goes straight back into new projects.公司利潤的一大部分／主要部分又直接投入了新的專案計劃。
• I accept my portion of the blame.我承擔部分責任。
the amount of a particular food that is served to one person, especially in a restaurant or a shop that sells food ready to be eaten
• The portions are very generous in this restaurant.這家餐廳每道菜量都很足。
to speak to a god either privately or in a religious ceremony in order to express love, admiration, or thanks or in order to ask for something
• She knelt and prayed silently.她跪下默默祈禱。
• Let us pray for the victims of this terrible disaster.讓我們為這次可怕災難的受害者祈禱吧。
• We're praying for good weather for tomorrow's game.我們祈禱明天的比賽有個好天氣。
• The two situations are quite different.兩種情況截然不同。
• The colours almost match but not quite.顏色差不多相配，但不完全協調。
• I enjoyed her new book though it's not quite as good as her last one.我喜歡她的新書，儘管沒有她上一本那麼好。
• Quite honestly/frankly, the thought of it terrified me.坦白/坦率地講，想到它我就害怕。
an angry disagreement between two or more people or groups
• They had a bitter quarrel about/over some money three years ago and they haven't spoken to each other since.他們三年前因為錢的問題有過一次激烈的爭吵，從此以後就互不理睬了。
• We have no quarrel with the people of your country (= we have no reason to disagree with or dislike them).我們沒有理由對貴國的人民感到不滿。
• They seem to have patched up their quarrel (= finished their disagreement and started to be friendly).他們似乎在爭吵後言歸於好了。
• What did you quarrel about/over?你們為甚麼而爭吵？
• She quarrelled with everyone in the village.她跟村裡的每一個人都爭吵過。
to go through an area making a lot of noise and causing damage
• The demonstrators rampaged through the town, smashing windows and setting fire to cars.示威者們橫衝直撞穿過城鎮，沿途砸壞窗戶、燒毀車輛。
• Several villages were destroyed by rampaging soldiers.好幾個村子被狂暴撒野的士兵搗毀。
• Rioters went on a/the rampage through the city.暴亂分子在城中橫衝直撞，胡作非為。
(a period of) extreme or violent anger
（一陣）盛怒；（一陣）狂怒；（一陣）暴怒
• Her sudden towering rages were terrifying.她突然暴跳如雷，很嚇人。
• I was frightened because I had never seen him in such a rage before.以前從未見他如此狂怒，我被嚇壞了。
• He flew into a fit of rage over the smallest mistake.微不足道的小錯誤就會使他大發雷霆。
an exciting or entertaining event involving a lot of activity
• The party was a rage.派對辦得熱鬧極了。
• He raged at (= spoke angrily to) us for forgetting to order a replacement.我們忘了訂購替換件，他對我們大發雷霆。
to happen in a strong or violent way
• The storm raged outside.屋外暴風雨大作。
• A flu epidemic is raging in/through local schools.一場流感在當地各學校肆虐。
• The argument rages on (= continues strongly).正在進行激烈的爭論。
to answer someone quickly in an angry or funny way
• [ + speech ] ",That doesn't concern you!" she retorted.「那不關你的事！」她反駁道。
(of fruit or crops) completely developed and ready to be collected or eaten
• Those bananas aren't ripe yet - they're still green.那些香蕉還沒有成熟——還是綠的。
• The summer sunshine ripened the melons.在夏日陽光的照射下，瓜熟了。
• These melons are ripening nicely.這些瓜馬上就熟透了。
to develop to a suitable condition for something to happen
• My plans are ripening - now all I need is official approval.我的計劃就要瓜熟蒂落了——現在就差官方的批准了。
a dark yellow substance obtained from a flower and used as a spice to give colour and flavour to food
番紅花粉（用於給食物增色提味）
Savoury food is salty or spicy and not sweet in taste.
• a savoury dish/sauce/flavour帶鹹味的一道菜／一種調料／一種味道
• A pie can be sweet or savoury.餡餅可以是甜的或鹹的。
If you say that something is not savoury, you mean that it is not pleasant or socially acceptable.
令人愉快的；名聲好的；受歡迎的
• That hotel doesn't have a very savoury reputation.那家旅館的聲譽不太好。
to take something quickly and keep or hold it
• I seized his arm and made him turn to look at me.我抓住他的手臂，使他轉身看著我。
• The rebels have seized ten soldiers to use as hostages.叛亂者俘獲了十名士兵作爲人質。
• Political instability helped the army to seize power.政治動盪使軍隊攫取了權力。
• Troops yesterday seized control of the broadcasting station.昨天部隊奪取了廣播電台的控制權。
If the police or other officials seize something, they take possession of it with legal authority.
• Customs officers at Heathrow have seized 60 kilos of heroin.希思洛機場的海關官員查獲了60公斤海洛因。
If a strong emotion or pain seizes you, you feel it suddenly.
• I was suddenly seized by/with a feeling of great insecurity and loneliness.我突然感到很沒有安全感，很孤獨。
to hit someone or something forcefully with the flat inside part of your hand, producing a short, loud noise, especially as a way of punishing a child:
• I'll smack your bottom if you don't behave yourself.
a main meal eaten in the evening
• Why don't you come to/for supper tonight?你今天一起來吃晚飯好嗎?
• 你今天一起來吃晚飯好嗎?他們早早吃完晚飯，去看電影了。
a small meal eaten in the late evening
• We usually have tea at about 5.30 p.m. , then supper before we go to bed.
• 我們通常會在下午五點半吃晚飯，然後在睡覺前再吃些夜宵。
• I slept terribly last night.我昨晚睡得很不好。
hard work, especially work that makes you feel physically tired
• Lindi has achieved her comfortable life only after years of hard toil.林迪在做了多年的苦工後才過上舒適的生活。
• Farm workers have been toiling in the 100-degree heat over the past week.在過去的一週中農場工人一直在100華氏度的高溫下艱苦工作。
• After toiling away at work all week, it's good to relax.在辛苦工作整整一個星期後，放鬆一下挺好。
